entry.title: Finance with Hledger and Ledger
entry.content:
Ledger is a tool to track the personal finances using a technique called double entry bookkeeping.¬†https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-entry_bookkeeping
The idea is to use a plain text to write down the expenses and assets, and use a cli tool like ledger of hledger to generated different types of reports.
I tried it before but found extremely tedious to input the expenses, and my partner wants to use a spreadsheet to keep things simpler.
I found that there is a tool to easily enter transactions via the cli. It is called hledger-iadd. <https://github.com/hpdeifel/hledger-iadd>
Unfortunetely I could only find installation and builds of the binary for Arch linux. I installed in my EndeavourOS Installation.
I enter the transactions with it, and then later I do some alterations in python to generate the report to paste on the spreadsheet.


#!/usr/bin/python3
import csv
import sys
from datetime import datetime
# Define the expense mapping dictionary
expense_mapping = {
'expenses:bank fee': 'Bank fee',
'expenses:clothing': 'Clothing',
'expenses:food/dining out': 'Food/Dining Out',
'expenses:groceries': 'Groceries',
'expenses:health': 'Health',
'expenses:pharmacy': 'Pharmachy',
'expenses:house': 'House',
'expenses:insurance': 'Insurance',
'expenses:internet': 'Internet',
'expenses:shopping': 'Shopping',
'expenses:transportation': 'Transportation',
'expenses:trips': 'Trips',
'expenses:union': 'Union'
}


def map_expenses(reader):
# Read the CSV input and apply the mapping
for row in reader:
category = row[2] ¬†# Assuming the category is in the third column
mapped_category = expense_mapping.get(category, 'Other')
date_obj = datetime.strptime(row[0], '%Y/%m/%d')
formatted_date = date_obj.strftime('%m/%d/%Y')
amount = row[3].split()[0] ¬†# Assuming the amount is in the fourth column
print(','.join([formatted_date, row[1], mapped_category, amount]))


if __name__ == "__main__":
# Read from stdin as CSV
reader = csv.reader(sys.stdin)
map_expenses(reader)

Here is the script I use to generate the report. e.g.: 


./export.sh jan


$ cat export.sh 
#!/bin/bash


if [ -z "$1" ]; then
    echo "Period is not set. Aborting."
    exit 1
fi
PERIOD=$1
ledger -f 2024.journal --period $PERIOD register --depth=2 --format='%(date),1221141,%(account),%(amount(number))\n' expenses | ./tocsv.py

entry.title: Parse WordPress to Markdown
entry.content:
I already expressed my attempts to use wordpress but save a backup of the website in markdown (at least the posts) here¬†Managed/ to make a markdown backup from wordpress, and here¬†Ensure/ Markdown is the true format of my posts.
I believe I found the best way to achieve that. The backup is done in two stages.

First step

Create a backup in json. For this I wrote a python script that reads from the database and saves the dates, slugs, tags and content in a json. The content still in html.


import mysql.connector
import json
import re
import os
import shutil
from urllib.parse import unquote


# Replace these with your WordPress MySQL database credentials
db_config = {
    'host': 'localhost',
    'user': 'wordpress',
    'password': 'password',
    'database': 'wordpress',
}


# Specify the base folder for saving posts and images
base_folder = "posts"


# Create the base folder if it doesn't exist
if not os.path.exists(base_folder):
    os.makedirs(base_folder)


attachment_paths = []
def update_links(match):
    link = match.group(0)


    # Check if the link is an attachment
    if 'wp-content/uploads' in link:
        # Extract the path after /uploads
        path_after_uploads = link.split('/uploads', 1)[-1]


        # Remove IP from the link and update to reference a folder
        updated_link = f'/uploads{path_after_uploads}'


        # Save the path of the attachment file to the list
        attachment_paths.append(updated_link)


        return updated_link


    # Check if the link is to another post
    elif '192.168.1.217' in link:
        # Extract the post slug from the link
        slug = link.split('/')[-1]


        # Replace the link with the post slug
        updated_link = f'/{slug}/'
        return updated_link


    # If it's a different type of link, leave it unchanged
    return link


# Establish a connection to the WordPress MySQL database
try:
    connection = mysql.connector.connect(**db_config)
    cursor = connection.cursor()


    # Query to fetch post titles
    query = """
    SELECT
        post_date AS creation_date,
        post_modified AS update_date,
        post_title AS title,
        post_name AS slug,
        post_content AS content,
        GROUP_CONCAT(DISTINCT terms.name) AS tags,
        post_status AS status
    FROM
        wp_posts
    LEFT JOIN
        wp_term_relationships ON wp_posts.ID = wp_term_relationships.object_id
    LEFT JOIN
        wp_term_taxonomy ON wp_term_relationships.term_taxonomy_id = wp_term_taxonomy.term_taxonomy_id
    LEFT JOIN
        wp_terms AS terms ON wp_term_taxonomy.term_id = terms.term_id
    WHERE
        post_type = 'post'
        AND post_status = 'publish'
    GROUP BY
        wp_posts.ID
    ORDER BY
        post_date DESC;
    """


    # Execute the query
    cursor.execute(query)


    # Fetch all rows
    posts = cursor.fetchall()


    # Print the titles of all posts
    for post in posts:
        creation_date = post[0]
        content = post[4]
        slug = unquote(post[3])
        # Generate filename based on creation date and slug
        filename = f"{creation_date.strftime('%Y%m%d%H%M%S')}_{slug}.json"
        # Update links in the content
        updated_content = re.sub(r'https?://192\.168\.1\.217\S+', update_links, content)
     # Create a dictionary with post details
        post_data = {
            "creation_date": creation_date.strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S'),
            "update_date": post[1].strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S'),
            "title": post[2],
            "slug": slug,  
            "content": updated_content.splitlines(),
            "tags": post[5].split(','),
            "status": post[6]
        }
        # Generate filename based on creation date and slug
        filename = os.path.join(base_folder, f"{creation_date.strftime('%Y%m%d%H%M%S')}_{slug}.json")


        # Save post data to a JSON file in the "posts" folder
        with open(filename, 'w') as json_file:
            json.dump(post_data, json_file, ensure_ascii=False, indent=4)


        print(f"Saved {filename}")


    print("\nAttachment Paths:")
    for path in attachment_paths:
        print(path)
    uploads_folder = os.path.join(base_folder, "uploads")


    shutil.copytree('/var/www/wordpress/wp-content/uploads',uploads_folder, dirs_exist_ok=True)


except mysql.connector.Error as err:
    print(f"Error: {err}")


finally:
    # Close the cursor and connection
    if 'cursor' in locals() and cursor is not None:
        cursor.close()
    if 'connection' in locals() and connection.is_connected():

Second step

Using javascript/typescript and deno, run a script taht reads the jsons and converts to markdown. This is easily done using¬†unifiedjs project.
The script even adds a . for the internal links, making sure that they are rendered ok in github.

import rehypeParse from "npm:rehype-parse";
import rehypeRemark from "npm:rehype-remark";
import remarkStringify from "npm:remark-stringify";
import remarkGfm from "npm:remark-gfm";
import removeComments from "npm:remark-remove-comments";
import rehypeStringify from "npm:rehype-stringify";


import * as path from "https://deno.land/std@0.97.0/path/mod.ts";
import { copy, ensureDir } from "https://deno.land/std@0.97.0/fs/mod.ts";






import { unified } from "npm:unified";


try {
  let dirName = "./posts";
  let mdDirName = "./md";
  const dirEntries = await Deno.readDir(dirName);
  const uploadsSet = new Set<string>();


  for await (const entry of dirEntries) {
    if (entry.isFile) {
      const filePath = `${dirName}/${entry.name}`;
      const fileContent = await Deno.readTextFile(filePath);
      const fileJson = await JSON.parse(fileContent);
      const mdFile = await parseToMd(fileJson, uploadsSet);
      const mdFilePath = `${mdDirName}/${path.parse(entry.name).name + ".md"}`;
      await Deno.writeTextFile(mdFilePath, mdFile);
    }
  }
  // Print the set of links after the main loop
  await Promise.all(Array.from(uploadsSet).map(async (filePath) => {
    const sourcePath = `./posts${filePath}`;
    const destinationPath = `./md${filePath}`;
    await ensureDir(path.dirname(destinationPath));


    await copy(sourcePath, destinationPath, { overwrite: true });
  }));
console.log('md done');
} catch (error) {
  console.log(error);
}


async function parseToMd(jsonFile, uploadsSet) {
  let md = "";
  let frontmatter = `---
title: "${jsonFile.title}"
created: "${jsonFile.creation_date}"
lastmod: "${jsonFile.update_date}"
slug: "${jsonFile.slug}"
draft: ${jsonFile.status === "published" ? false : true}
tags:
`;


  for (const tag of jsonFile.tags) {
    frontmatter += `  - ${tag}\n`;
  }
  frontmatter += `---\n`;


  let cnt = jsonFile.content.map((line) => {
    if (line === "") {
      line = "\n";
    }
    return line;
  }).join("\n\n");




  const body = await unified()
    .use(rehypeParse, { fragment: true })
    .use(() => prependDotToImagePath(uploadsSet))
    .use(rehypeRemark)
    .use(remarkGfm)
    .use(removeComments)
    .use(remarkStringify)
    .process(cnt);


  const mdContent = String(body);
  return frontmatter + "\n" + mdContent;
}


function prependDotToImagePath(uploadsSet) {
  const visit = (node) => {
    if (node.type === "element" && node.properties) {
      // Handle img tags
      if (
        node.tagName === "img" && node.properties.src &&
        node.properties.src.startsWith("/uploads")
      ) {
        uploadsSet.add(node.properties.src);
        node.properties.src = `.${node.properties.src}`;
      }


      // Handle a tags
      if (
        node.tagName === "a" && node.properties.href &&
        node.properties.href.startsWith("/uploads")
      ) {
        uploadsSet.add(node.properties.href);
        node.properties.href = `.${node.properties.href}`;
      }
    }


    if (node.children) {
      node.children.forEach(visit);
    }
  };


  return (tree) => {
    tree.children.forEach(visit);
  };
}

Might need to update scripts when i find errors, but so far is good enough.

entry.content:
As I wrote in a previous post, I want to use wordpress but still want to make markdown backups from my posts to make it future proof.
I think I managed to get this working using python and the wp export.

wp export --allow-root --with_attachments --skip_comments --path=/var/www/wordpress
mkdir -p bkp
source ./bin/activate
python3 wx3.py 1221141.wordpress.*.xml -o bkp
cd bkp
cp -r /var/www/wordpress/wp-content .
git add .
git commit -m "$(date)"
git push

The w3x.py script is an adaption of http://https://gist.github.com/ruslanosipov/b748a138389db2cda1e8

entry.title: Thoughts on wordpress
entry.content:
I have never worked with WordPress before, since I've never felt the need to write anything online and when if finally decided the whole static site generators were the new trend.
I tend to really like to keep my own data, so I thought it was the best way to keep my notes and thoughts. But since now I've been self-hosting my own applications it felt that might be ok to at least try wordpress. So far I am liking, but I definitely need to find a way to export the posts to markdown for long time storage.
I've been trying to use the combo {text editor, markdow, git, hugo}, and I really miss something where I can write from my phone.

My Data

I want to write and not really spend time tinkering with scripts and renaming stuff. I might need to write another script to export the data from wordpress. But since I am self hosting I can say that the data is mine and I can do that in later time.
I also want to automate some posts creations, since I also want to use this to bookmark some websites that I find interesting.
Well, time to spend time learning about wordpress, but I guess this will be repetitively easy, since it has been going from a long time and there is a lot of resources online.
